name: Guwahati
summary: The gateway to Northeast India, Guwahati is a sprawling city on the banks of the Brahmaputra River, known for ancient temples and vibrant markets.
history: Guwahati, formerly known as Pragjyotishpura, has been an important cultural and trading center since ancient times. It served as the capital of the Kamarupa Kingdom and has been a seat of Tantric Hinduism.

explore.title: Kamakhya Temple
explore.desc: One of the 51 Shakti Peethas, this ancient temple is a major pilgrimage site

explore.title: Brahmaputra River Cruise
explore.desc: Enjoy sunset cruises on the mighty Brahmaputra River

explore.title: Umananda Island
explore.desc: Visit the world's smallest inhabited river island with its Shiva temple

explore.title: State Museum
explore.desc: Explore Assam's rich cultural heritage and artifacts

pois.title: Kamakhya Temple
pois.desc: Ancient Hindu temple dedicated to goddess Kamakhya

pois.title: Fancy Bazaar
pois.desc: Bustling market for local goods and traditional items

pois.title: Assam State Zoo
pois.desc: Home to various wildlife including the one-horned rhinoceros

name: Jorhat
summary: Known as the 'Tea Capital of the World', Jorhat is surrounded by tea gardens and is the cultural capital of Assam.
history: Jorhat served as the last capital of the Ahom Kingdom. The city has been a center of Assamese culture and is home to many historical monuments from the Ahom era.

explore.title: Tea Garden Tours
explore.desc: Visit sprawling tea estates and learn about tea production

explore.title: Majuli Island
explore.desc: Explore the world's largest river island and its Vaishnavite monasteries

explore.title: Gibbon Wildlife Sanctuary
explore.desc: Spot hoolock gibbons in their natural habitat

pois.title: Raja Maidam
pois.desc: Royal burial ground of Ahom kings

name: Kaziranga National Park
summary: UNESCO World Heritage Site, Kaziranga is famous for the one-horned rhinoceros and is a treasure trove of wildlife in the heart of Assam.
history: Established in 1908, Kaziranga National Park was declared a UNESCO World Heritage Site in 1985. It was created to protect the Great Indian One-horned Rhinoceros and has since become one of India's most successful conservation stories.

explore.title: Jeep Safari
explore.desc: Spot one-horned rhinos, elephants, and tigers on guided jeep safaris

explore.title: Elephant Safari
explore.desc: Get close to wildlife on traditional elephant back rides

explore.title: Bird Watching
explore.desc: Observe over 480 bird species in their natural habitat

explore.title: Brahmaputra River Views
explore.desc: Enjoy scenic views of the mighty Brahmaputra from the park

pois.title: Kohora Range
pois.desc: Main safari range with highest rhino population

pois.title: Bagori Range
pois.desc: Western range known for bird watching

name: Shivasagar
summary: The ancient capital of the Ahom Kingdom, Shivasagar is a treasure trove of historical monuments, temples, and architectural marvels from medieval Assam.
history: Shivasagar served as the capital of the Ahom Kingdom for nearly 600 years until 1826. Originally known as Rangpur, it was renamed Shivasagar after the construction of the Shivasagar tank by Queen Madambika in 1734.

explore.title: Rang Ghar
explore.desc: Visit Asia's oldest amphitheater built by the Ahom kings

explore.title: Talatal Ghar
explore.desc: Explore the multi-storied palace with secret tunnels

explore.title: Shiva Dol
explore.desc: See the tallest Shiva temple in India built in 1734

explore.title: Kareng Ghar
explore.desc: Tour the ruins of the Ahom royal palace

explore.title: Gaurisagar
explore.desc: Visit the historic tank and temples complex

pois.title: Rang Ghar
pois.desc: Two-storied oval-shaped amphitheater from Ahom era

pois.title: Shiva Dol
pois.desc: Tallest Shiva temple in India at 104 feet

name: Majuli Island
summary: The world's largest river island, Majuli is the cultural capital of Assam, famous for its Vaishnavite monasteries, traditional arts, and unique river island ecosystem.
history: Majuli has been the cultural heartland of Assam since the 16th century when Saint Srimanta Sankardeva established the Neo-Vaishnavite movement here. The island has been gradually shrinking due to erosion by the Brahmaputra River.

explore.title: Satras (Monasteries)
explore.desc: Visit ancient Vaishnavite monasteries and witness traditional practices

explore.title: Traditional Mask Making
explore.desc: Watch artisans create traditional masks used in Bhaonas

explore.title: Pottery Villages
explore.desc: Explore villages known for traditional pottery and ceramics

explore.title: Bird Watching
explore.desc: Spot migratory birds in the wetlands and grasslands

explore.title: River Island Experience
explore.desc: Enjoy ferry rides and experience life on a river island

pois.title: Kamalabari Satra
pois.desc: Important Vaishnavite monastery with cultural performances

pois.title: Auniati Satra
pois.desc: Famous for traditional dance and drama

name: Haflong
summary: Known as the 'Hill Station of Assam', Haflong is a picturesque town nestled in the Dima Hasao district, offering stunning landscapes, lakes, and tribal culture.
history: Haflong is the headquarters of the Dima Hasao (formerly North Cachar Hills) district and is home to the Dimasa tribe. The town gained prominence as a hill station during British rule and is known for its scenic beauty and cultural diversity.

explore.title: Haflong Lake
explore.desc: Enjoy boating and scenic views at this beautiful lake

explore.title: Jatinga Bird Mystery
explore.desc: Witness the mysterious bird phenomenon at nearby Jatinga village

explore.title: Dimasa Cultural Village
explore.desc: Experience the rich culture and traditions of the Dimasa tribe

explore.title: Adventure Activities
explore.desc: Enjoy trekking, hiking, and nature walks in the hills

explore.title: Borail Range Views
explore.desc: Admire panoramic views of the Borail mountain range

pois.title: Haflong Lake
pois.desc: Scenic lake perfect for boating and picnics

pois.title: Jatinga Village
pois.desc: Famous for the mysterious bird suicide phenomenon

name: Itanagar
summary: The capital city of Arunachal Pradesh, Itanagar is known for its historical fort, Buddhist temples, and proximity to wildlife sanctuaries.
history: Itanagar's history dates back to the 14th-15th century when the Ita Fort was built. The city derives its name from 'Ita' meaning brick and 'Nagar' meaning city.

explore.title: Ita Fort
explore.desc: Explore the historical fort built with millions of bricks

explore.title: Buddhist Temple
explore.desc: Visit the beautiful Buddhist temple with Tibetan architecture

explore.title: State Museum
explore.desc: Learn about tribal culture and traditions

explore.title: Ganga Lake
explore.desc: Enjoy boating and picnics at this scenic lake

name: Tawang
summary: A high-altitude town famous for its Buddhist monastery, stunning landscapes, and Indo-China border proximity.
history: Tawang has been an important center of Tibetan Buddhism for centuries. The Tawang Monastery, founded in 1680, is the largest monastery in India.

explore.title: Tawang Monastery
explore.desc: Visit India's largest monastery and second largest in the world

explore.title: Sela Pass
explore.desc: Drive through this high-altitude pass with stunning views

explore.title: War Memorial
explore.desc: Pay respects at the memorial for 1962 Indo-China war martyrs

explore.title: P.T. Tso Lake
explore.desc: Visit this beautiful high-altitude lake

name: Shillong
summary: The 'Scotland of the East', Shillong is the capital of Meghalaya, known for its pine-covered hills, waterfalls, and vibrant music scene.
history: Shillong became the capital of Assam under British rule in 1874. After Meghalaya gained statehood in 1972, it became the state capital.

explore.title: Umiam Lake
explore.desc: Enjoy water sports at this scenic reservoir

explore.title: Elephant Falls
explore.desc: Visit the three-tiered waterfall

explore.title: Ward's Lake
explore.desc: Stroll around this horseshoe-shaped lake in the city center

explore.title: Police Bazaar
explore.desc: Shop for local handicrafts and enjoy street food

name: Cherrapunji
summary: Once the wettest place on Earth, Cherrapunji is famous for living root bridges, dramatic waterfalls, and limestone caves.
history: Known locally as Sohra, Cherrapunji was the first capital of the British in the Khasi Hills. It holds records for the highest rainfall in a calendar year.

explore.title: Double Decker Living Root Bridge
explore.desc: Trek to see the famous two-tier living root bridge

explore.title: Nohkalikai Falls
explore.desc: Visit India's tallest plunge waterfall

explore.title: Mawsmai Cave
explore.desc: Explore limestone caves with impressive formations

explore.title: Seven Sisters Falls
explore.desc: View the seven-segmented waterfall

pois.title: Living Root Bridge
pois.desc: Natural bridge made from living tree roots

name: Imphal
summary: The capital of Manipur, Imphal is known for its historical significance, cultural heritage, and the unique all-women's market.
history: Imphal has been the capital of Manipur since ancient times. It played a crucial role in World War II as the site of the Battle of Imphal against Japanese forces.

explore.title: Kangla Fort
explore.desc: Explore the ancient seat of Manipur's rulers

explore.title: Ima Keithel
explore.desc: Shop at Asia's largest all-women's market

explore.title: War Cemetery
explore.desc: Pay respects at the WWII memorial

explore.title: Manipur State Museum
explore.desc: Learn about local history and culture

name: Moirang
summary: A historic town on the shores of Loktak Lake, known for its role in India's independence movement and ancient temples.
history: Moirang is where the flag of the Indian National Army was first hoisted on Indian soil in 1944. It has ancient connections to Manipuri folklore and the epic love story of Khamba-Thoibi.

explore.title: Loktak Lake
explore.desc: Visit the largest freshwater lake in Northeast India

explore.title: INA Museum
explore.desc: Learn about the Indian National Army's history

explore.title: Keibul Lamjao National Park
explore.desc: See the only floating national park in the world

explore.title: Thangjing Temple
explore.desc: Visit the ancient temple of the Moirang deity

pois.title: Loktak Lake
pois.desc: Largest freshwater lake in NE India

pois.title: INA Museum
pois.desc: Museum dedicated to Indian National Army

name: Aizawl
summary: The capital of Mizoram, perched on a ridge, Aizawl offers panoramic views, vibrant markets, and rich Mizo culture.
history: Aizawl was established in the 1890s as a military outpost during British rule. It became the capital of Mizoram when it achieved statehood in 1987.

explore.title: Solomon's Temple
explore.desc: Visit the impressive church with beautiful architecture

explore.title: Bara Bazaar
explore.desc: Shop for traditional Mizo textiles and handicrafts

explore.title: Mizoram State Museum
explore.desc: Learn about Mizo culture and history

explore.title: Durtlang Hills
explore.desc: Enjoy panoramic views of the city

name: Lunglei
summary: The second-largest city in Mizoram, Lunglei is known for its scenic beauty and serves as a base for exploring southern Mizoram.
history: Lunglei, meaning 'bridge of rock', gets its name from a natural bridge-like rock formation. It served as an important administrative center during British rule.

explore.title: Khawnglung Wildlife Sanctuary
explore.desc: Spot diverse wildlife in natural habitat

explore.title: Saikuti Hall
explore.desc: Attend cultural performances

explore.title: Thorangtlang Wildlife Sanctuary
explore.desc: Trek through pristine forests

name: Kohima
summary: The capital of Nagaland, Kohima is known for its WWII history, the Hornbill Festival, and stunning mountain views.
history: Kohima was the site of a crucial WWII battle that stopped the Japanese advance into India in 1944. It became the capital of Nagaland when the state was formed in 1963.

explore.title: War Cemetery
explore.desc: Visit the memorial for WWII Battle of Kohima

explore.title: Hornbill Festival
explore.desc: Experience Naga culture during the December festival

explore.title: State Museum
explore.desc: See traditional Naga artifacts and costumes

explore.title: Kisama Heritage Village
explore.desc: Explore traditional Naga village life

name: Dimapur
summary: The commercial hub of Nagaland and gateway to the state, Dimapur has ancient ruins and serves as the main entry point.
history: Dimapur was the capital of the Kachari Kingdom before its fall in the 13th century. The ruins of the kingdom can still be seen today.

explore.title: Kachari Ruins
explore.desc: Explore ancient megalithic structures

explore.title: Dimapur Market
explore.desc: Shop for local produce and handicrafts

explore.title: Rangapahar Reserve Forest
explore.desc: Spot wildlife in natural habitat

name: Gangtok
summary: The capital of Sikkim, Gangtok offers stunning views of Kanchenjunga, Buddhist monasteries, and adventure activities.
history: Gangtok became the capital of the Kingdom of Sikkim in the mid-19th century. After Sikkim joined India in 1975, it continued as the state capital.

explore.title: Rumtek Monastery
explore.desc: Visit one of Buddhism's most important monasteries

explore.title: MG Road
explore.desc: Stroll along the pedestrian-only shopping street

explore.title: Tsomgo Lake
explore.desc: Visit the glacial lake at 12,400 feet

explore.title: Nathula Pass
explore.desc: Drive to the Indo-China border

name: Pelling
summary: A hill station offering breathtaking views of Kanchenjunga, Pelling is known for its monasteries and adventure activities.
history: Pelling has gained prominence as a tourist destination in recent decades. The area has historical significance with ancient monasteries like Pemayangtse.

explore.title: Pemayangtse Monastery
explore.desc: Visit the 300-year-old monastery

explore.title: Skywalk
explore.desc: Walk on India's first glass skywalk

explore.title: Rabdentse Ruins
explore.desc: Explore the ruins of Sikkim's former capital

explore.title: Khecheopalri Lake
explore.desc: Visit the sacred wish-fulfilling lake

name: Agartala
summary: The capital of Tripura, Agartala is known for its palaces, temples, and rich cultural heritage blending tribal and Bengali traditions.
history: Agartala served as the capital of the Manikya kings of Tripura. The city has a history spanning over 500 years and became the state capital when Tripura joined India.

explore.title: Ujjayanta Palace
explore.desc: Tour the magnificent royal palace turned museum

explore.title: Tripura Sundari Temple
explore.desc: Visit one of the 51 Shakti Peethas

explore.title: Heritage Park
explore.desc: Explore miniature models of Tripura's landmarks

explore.title: State Museum
explore.desc: Learn about Tripura's history and culture

pois.title: Ujjayanta Palace
pois.desc: Former royal palace, now a museum

name: Udaipur
summary: Known as the 'Lake City of Tripura', Udaipur is famous for its temples, lakes, and historical significance.
history: Udaipur served as the capital of Tripura kingdom in the past. It houses several important temples including the famous Tripura Sundari Temple.

explore.title: Tripura Sundari Temple
explore.desc: Visit the famous Shakti Peeth

explore.title: Kalyan Sagar Lake
explore.desc: Enjoy the scenic lake views

explore.title: Bhuvaneswari Temple
explore.desc: Explore the ancient temple by the lake
